repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
**Problem**:

As of 10 July 2023, [EmmyLuaCodeStyle](https://github.com/CppCXY/EmmyLuaCodeStyle/commit/668b88dd4c540537046456cb75fb6e7b7b7b0e43) and [lua-language-server](https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/commit/065cc4e3266ac683fd60af8929b0c79038cfc930) support the `?` symbol for nilable types (e.g. `string?`). `neovim` mostly uses `|nil` (e.g., `string|nil`), although the `?` symbol appears in a few places.

**Solution**:

When possible, instances of `|nil` are replaced with `?` in the LSP runtime. e.g., `string|nil` becomes `string?`. This can't be done in cases where the union is more than two different types. e.g. `string|int|nil`. This means we cannot use `sed` since that would lead to many false positives.

**Overall goal**:

Ideally we would replace `|nil` in all runtime modules, but that will be too large for one PR. If this PR is approved then I will make more PRs for each runtime. 

An alternative to this approach is to make PRs for each runtime to this branch. This will make it easier for reviewers and then we get the benefit of having only one commit to master. This is my first PR to `neovim`, so I don't know what is preferred by the devs here.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
---@param bufnr? integer Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer
```

The optional marker goes on the argument name, not type, and parens are no longer needed. Please change that everywhere.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,7 +78,7 @@ end
 
 --- Returns the buffer number for the given {bufnr}.
 ---
----@param bufnr (integer|nil) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer
+---@param bufnr (integer?) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer

comment_data.body: Except return type; there it's correct, I think.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,7 +78,7 @@ end
 
 --- Returns the buffer number for the given {bufnr}.
 ---
----@param bufnr (integer|nil) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer
+---@param bufnr (integer?) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer

comment_data.body:
It can go on both. When on the type it indicates the value may be nil but should be provided, and when on the arg name it indicates the argument is completely optional.

In practice, LuaLS won't ever be able to check this, but there is a semantic difference. In Lua you can detect the number of call arguments with `select('#', ...)` for vararg functions which will give you 2 for `foo(nil, nil)`.

With that said, we should probably prefer the `?` on the arg name like you suggested.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,7 +78,7 @@ end
 
 --- Returns the buffer number for the given {bufnr}.
 ---
----@param bufnr (integer|nil) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer
+---@param bufnr (integer?) Buffer number to resolve. Defaults to current buffer

comment_data.body:
I believe it makes a difference for the dreaded "missing field" diagnostic, which somewhat triggered this push...

(Apart from that, my argument is mostly from consistency and "neatness", I have to admit.)

comment_data.body: looks like there are some problems with docgen now?

         (table) result Map of client_id:request_result.
-        (string|nil) err On timeout, cancel, or error, `err` is a string
+        string?|nil err On timeout, cancel, or error, `err` is a string

comment_data.body:
Yes. I plan on looking into this tomorrow evening. I don't have time today due to work.

I don't know anything about docgen, so hopefully there is some flag to disable the manually appending `|nil` behavior.

comment_data.body:
The docgen is an ad-hoc flow that is developed just enough for it to work. You'll need to dig into the doxygen filter so it can handle `?`.

This is partly why I haven't already converted everything to `?`.

     -- fix optional parameters
     if magic_split[2]:find('%?$') then
-      if not ty:find('nil') then
-        ty = ty  .. '|nil'
+      if not ty:find('?') then
+        ty = ty  .. '?'

comment_data.body: This change will affect other generated types in documentation. I only pushed changes for the LSP module though. Should I push changes for _every_ module? I haven't modified non-LSP modules yet. But as I type this, I think it's best to push all docs that are modified by these changes. I'll update the PR.

comment_data.body:
Questions for clairty:

- Do we want parentheses around the type? I think the parentheses improve readability. Parentheses usage in this file is inconsistent, so I could work on improving this is future PRs.

- Is this syntax correct? (e.g. `NAME: TYPE DESCRIPTION`) The syntax for the table entries looks more appropriate in my opinion (`NAME TYPE: DESCRIPTION`). I don't have enough contextual knowledge to know why they're different. But this could be another "consistency" task for the future.

comment_data.body:
- Yes
- For Lua annotations? Both wrong. It should be `NAME TYPE DESCRIPTION`.
  The syntax is `---@param <name[?]> <type[|type...]> [description]` https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/wiki/Annotations#param

-        magic:gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '|nil)%)', 'param %1 %2')

+      magic =

comment_data.body: `any` was used quite frequently, so I thought it appropriate to add it to `TYPES`.
Arrays weren't previously matched. This is why there are many diffs adding parentheses around array types.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -158,6 +158,18 @@ local function removeCommentFromLine(line)
   return line:sub(1, pos_comment - 1), line:sub(pos_comment)
 end
 
+--- Add possible pattern variations to a type. This includes arrays, and
+--- optional types.
+---
+---@param type string
+---@return string
+local function addPossibleTypeCaptureGroups(type)
+  -- [%[%]]* : match any dimensional array

comment_data.body: This will match stuff like `||||`, `nnininil|||nni`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -158,6 +158,18 @@ local function removeCommentFromLine(line)
   return line:sub(1, pos_comment - 1), line:sub(pos_comment)
 end
 
+--- Add possible pattern variations to a type. This includes arrays, and
+--- optional types.
+---
+---@param type string
+---@return string
+local function addPossibleTypeCaptureGroups(type)
+  -- [%[%]]* : match any dimensional array
+  -- [%?]* : match `?` option type (e.g., `string?`)
+  -- [|nil]* : match `|nil` option type (e.g., `string|nil`)

comment_data.body:
Doing this with a single Lua pattern won't scale very well. Especially using the `[...]*` trick.

Using multiple patterns is fine as long as each pattern does one specific thing.

I think all this block is doing is removing parenthesis. Could it not be simplified to(?):

```lua
magic = magic:gsub('%(([^)]+)%)', '%1')
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -201,16 +213,15 @@ local function process_magic(line, generics)
 
   if directive == 'param' then
     for _, type in ipairs(TYPES) do
-      magic = magic:gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. ')%)', 'param %1 %2')
-      magic =
-        magic:gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '|nil)%)', 'param %1 %2')
+      magic = magic
+        :gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. addPossibleTypeCaptureGroups(type) .. ')%)', 'param %1 %2')
     end
     magic_split = vim.split(magic, ' ', { plain = true })
     type_index = 3
   elseif directive == 'return' then
     for _, type in ipairs(TYPES) do
-      magic = magic:gsub('^return%s+.*%((' .. type .. ')%)', 'return %1')
-      magic = magic:gsub('^return%s+.*%((' .. type .. '|nil)%)', 'return %1')
+      magic = magic
+        :gsub('^return%s+.*%((' .. addPossibleTypeCaptureGroups(type) .. ')%)', 'return %1')

comment_data.body: This will match 0 or more consecutive `?`.

-        magic:gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '|nil)%)', 'param %1 %2')
+      magic = magic
+        :gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '|nil)%)', 'param %1 %2') -- verbose optional type
+        :gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '%[%]|nil)%)', 'param %1 %2') -- verbose optional array
+        :gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '[%?]?)%)', 'param %1 %2') -- non-nil or optional type
+        :gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '%[%][%?]?)%)', 'param %1 %2') -- non-nil or optional array

comment_data.body:
You won't be able to do it using a single pattern.

The best way to handle this is to split the string, process each part separately and then rejoin.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -201,17 +201,17 @@ local function process_magic(line, generics)
 
   if directive == 'param' then
     for _, type in ipairs(TYPES) do
-      magic = magic:gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. ')%)', 'param %1 %2')
-      magic =
-        magic:gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '|nil)%)', 'param %1 %2')
+      magic = magic
+        :gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '|nil)%)', 'param %1 %2') -- verbose optional type
+        :gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '%[%]|nil)%)', 'param %1 %2') -- verbose optional array
+        :gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '[%?]?)%)', 'param %1 %2') -- non-nil or optional type
+        :gsub('^param%s+([a-zA-Z_?]+)%s+.*%((' .. type .. '%[%][%?]?)%)', 'param %1 %2') -- non-nil or optional array

comment_regular_data.body:
I see the failed build for not pushing updated docs. I will do that later today, and also look at some of the incorrectly generated types. 

EDIT: I will also troubleshoot the failed BSD build.
The runners are often flaky; for the purpose of this PR, I would not worry about it unless they all fail. (But since you only change comments, that should not be the case.)
Sorry for all of the pushes. But the PR is in a state that is ready for review. I won't be able to work on this again until thu 31 aug, but I'll respond to comments until then.

> spoke about this task in the matrix channel.

Please always give a concise summary of the purpose (Problem/Solution) of a PR in its commit message and PR, "discussed on matrix" isn't useful for observers or when looking at git logs.

Sorry for not working on this for 2 weeks. I am not abandoning this PR though, I will work on it more this week.

> Please always give a concise summary of the purpose (Problem/Solution) of a PR in its commit message and PR, "discussed on matrix" isn't useful for observers or when looking at git logs.

I'll update the PR description.

title: refactor(types): replace `|nil` with `?` for LSP runtime
